fields.label_text:
[Cocktail case]

Afternoon dress (robe après-midi habillée)
Jean Dessès (1904-70)
Paris
About 1955

Hybrid garments, suitable for both day and evening, often combined different fabrics. Here, the close fitting wool bodice has a modest, high neck and long sleeves. The skirt is made of pleated silk taffeta. Woman and Beauty (1951) advised, 'Invest your all in one good little black dress'.

Wool and silk taffeta

Worn by Mrs Opal Holt and given by Mrs Haynes and Mrs Clark
V&A: T.104-1982

[displayed with]
Hat
Simone Mirman, London
About 1955
Velvet and net
V&A: T.114-1980

DAY DRESS, plain weave wool and accordion-pleated silk taffeta.
French, Paris, Jean Desses, about 1955.

Perhaps the most desirable black dress is the one which can be worn with ease during both day and evening and demands nothing more than an accessory change. Here is such a comfortable, cool season dress with a modest, high-necked, long-sleeved bodice which front-fastens with self-covered buttons. From the narrow waist of non-reflective wool spreads a permanently pleated, calf-length lustrous silk taffeta skirt. During working hours accessories of white collar or coloured scarf, leather belt, sensible shoes and handbag would not look amiss, while at the witching hour these could be swiftly exchanged for evening pearls, patent belt, sandals and clutch bag. 1950s fashion magazines frequently included such 'transformation' advicen for the busy, well-dressed woman - and a basic black dress was the ideal starting point.

Worn by Mrs Opal Holt and given by Mrs D M Haynes and Mrs M Clark
T.104-1982

fields.descriptive_line: Cocktail dress in wool and sun-ray pleated silk taffeta, designed by Jean Dessès, Paris, ca. 1955

fields.name: The Golden Age of Couture. Paris and London 1947 - 1957

fields.physical_description: Black cocktail dress in wool and sun-ray pleated silk taffeta. Long sleeved top of matte wool with front fastening self-covered buttons to the waist.  Full skirt of sun-ray pleated silk taffeta.
fields.dimensions: Circumference: 100 cm bust, Circumference: 63 cm waist, Length: 77 cm skirt, Diameter: 100 cm footprint of skirt

DAY DRESS, plain weave wool and accordion-pleated silk taffeta.
French, Paris, Jean Desses, about 1955.

Perhaps the most desirable black dress is the one which can be worn with ease during both day and evening and demands nothing more than an accessory change. Here is such a comfortable, cool season dress with a modest, high-necked, long-sleeved bodice which front-fastens with self-covered buttons. From the narrow waist of non-reflective wool spreads a permanently pleated, calf-length lustrous silk taffeta skirt. During working hours accessories of white collar or coloured scarf, leather belt, sensible shoes and handbag would not look amiss, while at the witching hour these could be swiftly exchanged for evening pearls, patent belt, sandals and clutch bag. 1950s fashion magazines frequently included such 'transformation' advicen for the busy, well-dressed woman - and a basic black dress was the ideal starting point.

T.104-1982 [1983-84]
fields.public_access_description: The little black dress was a classic design. Women could wear them for work during the day and then, with a change of accessories, wear them out in the evening. This version was designed by Jean Dessès in about 1955. It has a modest bodice with a high neck and long sleeves. The bodice is made in matte wool and fastens in the front with self-covered buttons. It has been cut and fitted to fit closely. The skirt is made of pleated lustrous silk taffeta.
fields.exhibition_history:
Black in Fashion (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/01/1999-31/12/1999)
The Little Black  Dress (Victoria and Albert Museum 01/01/1983-31/12/1984)
The Golden Age of Couture. Paris and London 1947 - 1957 (Victoria and Albert Museum 22/09/2007-06/01/2008)
fields.bibliography: Mendes, Valerie. <u>Black In Fashion</u>. London: V&A Publications, 1999.
fields.credit: Given by Mrs D.M. Haynes and Mrs M. Clark
fields.history_note:
Opal Holt was born in Canada in 1887 but lived in the US until the end of the Second World War.  She travelled extensively between the wars and was in the first plane to land in Bali.  She married Herbert Holt, a Canadian who lived a large part of his life in England, as her third husband in 1946.  They came to England and Europe every summer and Opal Holt began buying clothes in Paris for her life in England, and for the Bahamas in Winter, over a period of about thirty years.  She died in 1980.

Given by Mrs D.M Haynes and Mrs. Clark (nee Holt; Opal Holt's step-daughters).
